title: I propose "They 115'ed it!" as the new "Jumped the Shark!"
content:
I propose "They 115'ed it!" as the new "Jumped the Shark!"

I have been using Thunderbird for so long I don't even know when I started. The last couple of years have seen updates that alter the UI and none of them have been things I wanted.

So for me, and perhaps you, the upgrade process (without asking) just like on other systems I've noticed recently (Slack), has been a progressive mandatory downgrade process. I do not think the "designers/engineers" have the slightest idea. Their goal, apparently, is change. Period. A constant seemingly compulsive re-organizing and over-engineering, when what is needed is *refinement* and leaving the layout to the users. People have their own workflow - DUH - and these upgrades are doing nothing for those who do *not* want to change the layout. Did the designers/engineers genuinely ask the question for each and every change no matter how small: "How does this impact our users and why is this needed?"

On the glitzy, page-after-page of huge screenshots of busy-ness, I was hit with the overwhelming feeling of "here's how to [deal with] your new upgrade". I saw a slider comparison of the two versions and I *immediately* liked the one on the right and *immediately* disliked the one on the left. It took me several looks to realize the one on the left *was the upgrade* ... :: eyes roll ::

Opened Thunderbird and I have lost all formatting, everything is overly compact and busy, a 1000 icons that all look the same where I don't want any, even my email summary list is squished and tedious to read and navigate and guess what? I now apparently have to see 9 of these at a time when I only want 4 or 5. Can't even control something that small - WTFGrrrrr Even the Thunderbird icon is whacked: it looks like a huge blue claw holding an egg it is about to crush - something really symbolic about that methinks...

This "upgrade" basically ruined my day and now I am grieving for yet another software package falling into Design Hell where apparently the designers/engineers don't care one bit - to them "the design is the thing" when actually "the users are the thing" and they have either forgotten or are never using it day-to-day in the real world.

I tried for a few minutes to find controls to turn things off and revert but frankly I do not have the time and energy to try to unwind someone else's crappy design decisions. I also *could not find anything useful*. I actually started looking for alternatives and am thinking about just doing web-based email - another project I didn't need to start...

Thunderbird should be about making my life easier and it just did the opposite, so thanks for the older versions but this one Jumped the Shark.

And thus I propose a new term for all software that goes this route: "They 115'ed it!"
